dialogues.text: Annie is returning from her jog, sweating. As she crosses her motel room, she stops by the window, looking in to se Grace, on the floor, straining to do her exercises. Annie fills with compassion for her girl -- reminded of t struggle she faces everyday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance, the Suburban and horse trailer look like dot on the horizon, moving across the Badlands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace leans against the window in the back, in one of her darker moods. Annie switches radio stations, from Bible  thumping to Farm reports. She shuts it off. Silence. She sees a ROAD SIGH: "LITTLE BIGHORN NATIONAL MONUMENT".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace, look! Grace reads the sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to see that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care. Annie's comic mimicking, throws Grace off center. Annie turns off onto the exit. They drive by a massive ca -- it's neon sign flickering. They drive up a hill past a two Indians in high crowned Cowboy hats standing outside the cafe. She drives up a hill towards the parking lot of Monument...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This'll be nice. We haven't seen any  of the sights yet. It's history. When  I was thirteen I used to love seeing  things like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were never thirteen, Mom. Annie laughs, taking it as a joke. Grace almost smiles. But, Annie drives up to sign only to find a CLOSED SIGN. park was closed at six. Annie stops the car. She's hit a  brick wall once more. Silence. Finally, Grace speaks with usual sarcasm;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great idea. So now what? Beat. Annie's patience snaps;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long is this going to go on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I mean? (turns to the back seat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this it now? Is this the way we're  going to be from now on? Ignoring her, Grace edges to the passenger side and exits car. Annie gets out of the driver's side and walks around she speaks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want us to turn around and go  back home? Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you asking me for? You didn't  ask me if I wanted to come in the first  place -- now I get to decide? Forget it! She begins to turn away. Annie grabs her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you think I'm doing this for?  I'm doing this for you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit! It's about you! About you  deciding! About you always being  right! You always getting everything  your way, controlling everybody --  like we work for you or something!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just want to get away from Daddy  and you're using me to do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true! Whatever problems your  father and I are having, have nothing  to do with this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're amazing! You act like I don't  live in that house! Don't you think I  hear the two of you!? Don't you think  I can tell what's going on? I'm not  five years old, Mom! (Annie is stopped)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to divorce Daddy and Daddy  doesn't want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he tell you that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't have to! It's, like, so  obvious you can't stand him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why do you want to leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's... it's not that simple to explain.  I know you think it is, but it's not.  The truth is, I don't really know what  I want to do. I don't have all the  answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you just act like you do. Annie is choked with fury. She doesn't know whether to  scream, cry or strangle Grace. She turns away and begins  walking quickly, blindly, up past a grove of trees. She c to a CEMETERY enclosed by a black railing. At the crest o the hill there's a stone monument "The Little Bighorn  Cemetery." In the growing darkness, she sees, scattered on the hills below her, white tombstones. A place of sorrow. A cool br ruffles her coat and she sticks her hands in her pockets. Frustrated, alone, at a complete loss as to what to do, w action to take -- Annie, for the first time in frozen,  standing still -- and with her, comes a rush of emotion. She sits with her back against the monument and begins to weep. For Grace, for Robert, herself, for the tombstones, everyone. A FLASHLIGHT shines on her face. It is a PARK RANGER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wipes face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That young lady is getting a little  worried. Annie realizes she left Grace alone as it got darker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm sorry... Annie rises and is escorted back to the Suburban by the  Ranger. She sees: Grace is sitting in the front seat now, waiting for her - like a little girl lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie gets into the driver's seat. Buckles up. Grace hold back tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You buckled up? (Grace nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little. Annie reaches into the back seat and pulls a blanket out, handing it to Grace, making sure it covers her. Grace tur towards the window and closes her eyes. Annie starts the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.U. on Pilgrim's head in the trailer as we PULL BACK to  reveal the Suburban coming down an empty, seemingly infin stretch of two-lane road in Montana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie and Grace, both in front seats, eating doughnuts an coffee. They stop. POV -- Through the windshield is an endless sky and a rol sea of land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, this looks like a fun place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't they believe in signs here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would they say? "Ten miles to big  rock." "Twenty miles to bigger rock."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was supposed to be a turn off.  Did I miss it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't see it. Their Suburban is the only vehicle on what seems like mil of road. Annie sighs and puts the Suburban in drive. EXT. PETERSON'S MOTEL & STABLES, RED FORK MONTANA - D The Suburban and the horse trailer, pulls into Peterson's collection of motel cottage adjacent to an expanse of lan that includes stable, corral, a main house and various ri trails into the mountains. Mr. Peterson runs out from the main house to greet Annie she gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie, showered and changed, is trying to follow Mr.  Peterson's directions to Tom's ranch -- written on Peters motel stationary. She is lost once again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... after left, stay on main road until  rise, then... (frustrated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What bloody rise?!? What main road!? She stops the Suburban (no longer carrying the trailer).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From outside the Suburban, we see, but cannot hear, Annie hitting the steering and cursing in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie, panting, looks ahead and sees nothing but empty sp above and below -- as if the earth and sky met with nothi between. She sighs and starts the car again. As she moves forward, senses an almost indistinguishable rise in the road -- as follow her POV up the road through the windshield to reve POV -- A BREATHTAKING VALLEY just beyond the rise, hidden from view only a few yards before. THE DOUBLE DIVIDE RANC sits nestled in the valley, a few miles away. Annie is  impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men are working in the corral, saddle horses standing nea trying to get a sick calf to suckle a cow. One of the men Tom Booker, working along side his brother FRANK, and his nephew, JOE. Frank is a good man -- solid work ethic,  Christian fearing, wry sense of humor. With the build of football player, his strength never overwhelms his boyish good-natured heart. Joe is eleven, wearing his cowboy hat like a badge of honor. The three men seem as inseparable each other, as they are to the land. As they work:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we take a look at Bronty's foal  when we're done here, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. As long as she don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a kid at school says we  should've imprint-trained him. Tom and Frank don't say anything. Just nod, knowingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says if you do it soon as they're  born, it makes them real easy to handle  later on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what some folks say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was this thing on the TV about a  guy who does it with geese. He has this  airplane and these baby geese all grow  up thinking it's their mom, and he flies  it and they just follow. (to Tom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear 'bout that, Uncle T?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I hear about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what do you think about that  stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Joe, I'll tell ya -- I don't know  a whole lot about geese. Maybe it's okay  for them to grow up thinking they're  airplanes. But horses, as far as I can  tell, can't fly. Frank laughs. Joe smirks as Tom messes his hat up. There' sound of a car. They turn. The Suburban is coming over the ridge, heading down the  driveway in a cloud of dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We expecting company? Frank shakes his head. As the Suburban slows down, Tom  recognizes the driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know her? Annie, out of her element, hiding behind sunglasses, gets as Tom approaches her by himself. Annie girds herself for confrontation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Booker. Annie MacLean. From  New York. We talked on the phone. She extends her hand. TOM shakes it, nodding, staring at curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's, uh... beautiful country. I had a  little bit of a hard time finding the  place. There are no signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plenty of signs -- just none of them  printed. Who do I get the idea you're  not just passing through!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... OK... here it is... Uh... I'd  like you to take a look at my horse.  Now -- it won't take long and if, after  that, you still don't feel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you thinking of personally driving  me back East?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. She's here. I brought him along.  And my daughter, too. We're staying at  Peterson's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you hauled him all the way out  here? Just like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slightly taken aback)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... yes... I had a trailer. It's not  like I made him run along side of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All by yourself? She nods. Tom cannot help be impressed by her guts and fo Camera cuts away for a moment to a window in the ranch ho through which DIANE -- Frank's fiery, loyal pioneer wife looks at the duo with suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I uh... ha, ha... I don't think I ever  met a lady quite like yourself and I  appreciate all the pains you've gone  through to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! Please! Don't do the "shucks,  ma'am" thing again! (Tom, surprised, listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've driven a few thousand miles for a  few minutes of your time. I've brought  him here -- to your neck of the... (seeing no woods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- mountains. Just take a look at him.  If you still feel the same way, I'll  be on the road by morning and you'll  never see me again. OK? Deal? Tom tries to hide a smile of respect. Annie, thinking she have him, starts backing away towards her car -- as one w a dangerous animal they think they might have tamed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're at Peterson's. Whenever you're  free. You don't even have to call. She gets into the Suburban. Tom watches her drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom walks up some wooden steps to a door and knocks. He h a TV on inside. And Grace's Voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOM! The door! He hears Annie's muffled reply from O.S. He hears some ba as Grace fumbles for her crutch and comes to the door. Sh opens it only so far as to reveal her upper body:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, I'm Tom Booker. Your mother  around? Grace hops to the side as Tom walks by her, into the room Grace is closing the door as he turns to see, for the fir time, that Grace is one leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be right out. She's on the  phone. Grace hops back to the bed in front of the TV. Tom nods a puts his hat down -- noticing the prosthetic leaning agai the window, near her bed. He hears Annie on the phone and looks to the other room, the door ajar -- seeing only her legs, seated on the edge of her bed, as she talks. Her fo taps impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First time in Montana? Grace, rudely nods, still looking at the TV. Beat. Tom doesn't like her manner, but can easily see thr it. He sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gonna be long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably. She's on the phone twenty- three hours a day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does she do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's an editor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm. An editor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not like books or literature or anything.  Just a magazine... Just in case she  hasn't told you -- which I'm sure she  hasn't -- I don't want to be a part of  this, OK? Tom just sort of nods. A beat or two later, Annie enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about that. Hi. Grace, this is  Mr. Booker... Have you looked at  Pilgrim? Tom sees Grace turn away, just as Annie enters. He takes moment. He could say no right there, but something stops

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, no. I was gonna take a look now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want us to come with you? I just  have to run to the main house and give  Mr. Peterson a check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace?... Grace, you want to come with  us, take a look at Pilgrim? Grace keeps looking at the TV. No reply. Tom is half way the door when he says to Annie -- making sure Grace can h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably best she stays behind, anyway. He disappears. Annie gives Grace a final look and exits, Alone, Grace flings her body across the bed, reaching for prosthetic -- putting it on feverishly. She is completely intrigued by Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom stands alone at the stable. Opening the bottom door,  ducking under the stall, he goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay now... Okay now... Walking towards him, Tom raises his hand, showing Pilgrim sign of respect, of trust... He quietly makes his way alo Pilgrim's side, along his flank, prompting Pilgrim to mov out from the shadows, into the light. Tom moves to look a him. And Pilgrim suddenly kicks out at him. Tom, not cowe stands his ground. He bends, looking at Pilgrim's withere legs. He looks up at his scarred head. He looks into the  pools of the horse's tortured eyes. Pilgrim stands still allowing Tom this brief intimacy. As Grace walks towards the stable, she realizes that the is open and Tom must be inside. She is amazed. Annie, appearing behind her, is also impressed. Tom exits the stable and sees them, as he closes the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... You're closest anyone's  gotten. He walks straight towards them -- veering more to Grace. stops in front of her and they look into each other's eye in a way that reminds us of how Tom looked at Pilgrim. Except, Grace is made even more uncomfortable by the inti She turns away and walks to the corral, to lean on a post as if she doesn't care. Tom turns to Annie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to be honest. I still feel  you made a long trip for nothing. He looks at Annie. Annie has no more words -- just an eve present pleading in her face. Tom watches as Grace makes a small, naked movement -- put her hand on her cheek, like a hurt child. He can't help but see these three being connected by one

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But before I even think about it, I  need to know something here and now.  It's a question for Grace here. Grace stiffens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I work with a horse, it's no good  just me doing it. It doesn't work that  way. The owner needs to be involved too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that'll be a little complicated --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can make it as complicated or as  easy as you like. But she's the one  who's gonna be riding him, am I right?  So here's the deal. I'm not sure I can  do anything, but I'm prepared to give  it a go -- (to Grace)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- if you'll help. (Grace gives a bitter laugh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a problem with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it like, obvious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to me. Either you want to or you  don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'll talk to Grace and call you  later--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, with all due respect, but  this is her decision, not yours. And I  don't want to waste anybody's time --  mostly mine. Grace reacts anew to Tom's remark. She likes her mother b dis-empowered. Annie keenly understands the importance of putting it this way to Grace. Grace has all eyes on her - just what she wants. All waiting for her response. She tu away, flicks her head and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's nothing else to do around  here. Annie smiles in relief. But Tom isn't satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not good enough. I can't help you. He starts walking away. Annie doesn't know what to do. Gr mumbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I have to do? Tom keeps walking out... Grace says it louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, what do I have to do?! Tom stops and looks at her. Annie holds her breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, Tom, Joe and TOM TWIN BOYS, 6 years old, sit at a table eating dinner, as Diane serves. We parachute into t middle of the conversation:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... well, I just think she's got a lot  of nerve showing up here. Draggin' that  child and that poor animal all the way... (TO ONE OF THE TWINS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You eat with those fingers again and you  know what'll happen! (the boy cowers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, don't you think she's got a nerve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh hell, I don't know... According to Tom,  she's a pretty determined woman. Must've  thought it was worth it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sits down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess they'll want feeding and all, out  here all day long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe they'll expect that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, they ain't going forty miles into  Choteau everytime they want a hamburger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mixed salad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slyly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe women from New York eat mixed  salads. Ain't that right, Tom? Tom hides a grin -- he knows Frank into teasing her now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe so. Saw it on a television  show, once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's just what we need on a cattle  ranch -- a vegetarian from New York. Everyone eats. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you figure on branding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weekend after next...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the weather holds. Frank nods. Silence again. Everyone eats. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's an editor do anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not sure, sweetheart, but they  eat like rabbits. Tom and Frank chuckle. Diane smiles -- in on the joke wit them. The children are curiously confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera moves to reveal Annie on the phone in front of her computer and fax...  plugging in extension cords as she t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... the phone company's putting in extra  lines. I'll call back with the numbers.  Oh, and I want you to get in touch with  this lady in town here -- they say she's  sort of a physical therapist for the  rodeo boys but keep the one at the  hospital we already contacted on call... Grace sits alone in the living room. Watching TV, but anx and disturbed about what she's committed herself to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diane is in her bathrobe doing bills at the kitchen table she listens to a BOOK OF TAPE. Her hand on her forehead, other hand writing. Tom enters to take his hat off the  sideboard. He moves to the table and reaches over for a  cookie from a plate of cookies. Without looking up, Diane slaps his hand. Tom then pours himself a cup of coffee... swiftly sneaks his hand back and grabs a cookie. Diane sm Tom exits. It is only then that Diane looks up after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera follows Tom towards his bedroom --  passing the ot Perhaps we see Frank sprawled out asleep already in his  underwear. We might see the Twins in their bunks. One of Twins' lower torso is laying outside of the blanket. He  casually flips the blanket over the kid's bare feet and  continues to his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom enters and closes the door. Turns on a stereo which p a cello piece by Yo-Yo Ma. Books fills his room. He sits his desk, puts on eye glasses and looks through some pape Suddenly he stops, looking over the paperwork, into space thought passes by. We don't know what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First light of day. Pilgrim stands stock still in the mid of the corral. Tom, motionless, is crouched on his haunch in the corral -- watching him. TOM'S POV: As Pilgrim moves, he can see that the horse is stove up. He softly tosses a handful of dirt at Pilgrim's withered  legs... Pilgrim, sensitive to the slightest provocation,  bucks, wheeling away from him. Then stops. Tom sits on hi haunches again... and watches him. Frank appears, exiting from the barn (perhaps).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Tom leaves Pilgrim, hooking up with Frank -- the two brot go off, discussing the ranch work that is ahead of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie and Grace arrive in the Suburban. They exit. As the head towards the ranch, they see in the distance: Pilgrim standing along the fence of a round pen. Tom stan in the pen, holding a rope, looking at Pilgrim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom stands in the pen with Pilgrim. He looks to see Annie Grace approaching but makes no acknowledgement. He turns focus back to Pilgrim. Annie and Grace appear. Grace takes a position (that is t become her regular spot) a distance away from the pen. An moves in closer, beside SMOKEY (a ranch hand) with one le up on the pen fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howdy... (sees Grace)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howdy. He and Annie watch as Tom stands before Pilgrim -- turnin sideways... then standing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trying to get his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going? Smokey doesn't respond -- how it's going is exactly how i looks. Tom takes a few steps, stops and stands still agai sense the process is long and requires great patience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hours later. Grace is in the same spot. Smokey is gon doing his work. Annie has taken a different position, loo over SEVERAL PAGES OF FAXES on her lap. Tom is still standing in the pen trying to get Pilgrim's Joe has joined the proceedings, sitting on the pen rail. Tom deftly throws a hoolihan, gently lassoing Pilgrim aro the neck. And Pilgrim, at the touch of the rope, crazed,  resists, pulling back, striking at the rope... The rope  cutting into Tom's hands. Tom gives him some slack, givin his head, letting him relax... then gently heads him by t rope, walking him around the pen, getting his feet to mov Grace's eyes never leave Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, off in the distance -- against a sky that seems to b touching the land -- is riding along a creek. Closer up, see he's rustling the bushes with a stick. Some stray cow run out of the bushes. Tom races after them. His horse  shepherds the cow across the creek and up a hillside. At the top of the hill, with the ranch spread out endless before him, Tom sees Frank on his horse, chasing strays. whistles. Frank waves back. In the near distance, a picku truck is parked on the range. Joe and the TWINS are throwing food pellets out of the ba of the truck. Cattle come from across the range for the f What begins as a handful of cows becomes dozens, then  hundreds -- the truck virtually disappearing among them. Tom stops for a moment to look out at his ranch. Far off the distance, he sees Annie's Suburban coming along the r to the ranch. He watches as Annie's distant figure gets o of the car with Grace. Annie instinctively turns and look across the land. Even though there is such a distance,  there's a sense Tom and Annie are looking at each other. Tom senses Joe driving Frank's truck, slowly moving off t range -- the Twins in the back, the cattle following. Tom on his horse atop the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilgrim, his scarred head above water, legs moving in odd sycopation, swimming. We discover he is in a pond, tether to a pole... Except for the sound of his legs in the wate everything is quiet and focused on Pilgrim. SMOKEY, holds the pole, walking on the outside of the pon leading Pilgrim back and forth as he swims. Tom, crouched the pond, silently concentrating on Pilgrim... Grace watches, off by herself... Annie stands beside Joe. can't help but be intrigued by the sight. She asks Joe;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I though horses were afraid of  water? Joe doesn't answer her. Grace likes that. Annie, frustrat feels she has the right to simple shout out to Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that to get his strength back? Tom pays her no mind -- concentrating on Pilgrim. Suddenly, Annie's CELL PHONE rings, jarring the proceedin Tom turns to Annie. She hides her embarrassment by answer it, walking away. Tom gives her a look. Grace is loving t Tom turns back to Pilgrim. After a few moments -- Tom, taking the rope tether, unhooks it from the pole. He starts to lead Pilgrim out of the water. Pilgrim, fearful fights him. He rears, splashing Tom, not wanting to come of the water. Grace is worried. She looks to Joe and sees is concerned too, though he stands quietly. Annie hears the commotion from where she stands and finis her call to return to the pond. Tom enters the pond, waist deep in water, trying to grab  Pilgrim's rope. Pilgrim rises up, rearing at him. Joe and Smokey, sensing danger, come closer to the pond. Annie  appears beside Grace and watches as Tom reaches for the r again. Pilgrim rears again. Tom stumbles backwards from h hooves. Annie gasps. Grace turns to walk away from the po She can't watch -- it brings back too much. But as she do she is stopped by the sight of -- Tom, righting himself, unphased, calmly walks back to Pil The horse, baffled by this man's lack of fear, lets him t the rope and walk him out of the pond. Grace can't help but be impressed. Joe nods. Annie is sha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Booker, I'm not at all comfortable  with you taking those kinds of chances... As Tom leads Pilgrim out, the horse suddenly whirls, bolt knocking Tom down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God! Pilgrim runs off, pulling the wet rope behind him. Joe ru over and grabs for the rope.

dialogues.speaker: NO... LET HIM GO
dialogues.text: Joe obeys. Pilgrim runs past the corral and down into a h out onto a pasture, He keeps on running into the distance running across the pasture, not knowing where he is going Tom, arms folded across his chest, watches him run. A  concerned Annie approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's running away! How are you going  to get him back? Tom doesn't respond. He walks off down the hill out onto pasture, stops, arms folded and watches Pilgrim. Annie tu when she hears Smokey, who appears behind her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't really want to run. Don't  know where he's going. All this open  space scares the daylight out of him. Confused, Pilgrim stops running and walks, in no particul direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My guess is he's spent his life in a  six-by-eight stall... He's forgot what  it's like to be a horse... Smokey ambles off and she turns back to see Tom crouching his haunches, sitting in the grass, just waiting. Pilgrim walks back towards the ranch, stops a distance from Tom,  looks at him... Annie, needing to know exactly what's goi on, crosses down the hill to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what now? Should we leave? Tom continues watching Pilgrim. Annie looks at him, sitti there motionless and feels like an idiot. Clearly she doe understand all this and clearly no one thinks this is the time to explain to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we're going to go then... Without looking at her, Tom just nods. Annie, awkwardly,  walks back up the hill to where Grace is... ON THE GRASSY HILLSIDE, Grace is watching the scene by he as Joe appears, staring at her leg... It makes her uncomf She turns to him with a curt, impatient tone;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Their eyes meet. Joe is so guileless, Grace is taken off when he asks in such a compassionate voice;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that hurt you? Grace tries to think of an answer -- and of how to say it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only when I kick somebody. Her gentle delivery makes him smile. She smiles, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you go to school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twice a month they give you a day off  to work on the ranch. He tips his hat down as he looks out to Pilgrim with resp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at him out in the pasture -- Yeah,  he must've been a big, beautiful looking  horse. How was he to ride? Grace is uncomfortable again. She looks away, just strugg Joe senses she's done talking;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. I got chores to look after. He tips his hat and walks off, passing Annie as she arriv

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ready to go? Grace hesitates. Then mother and daughter take one more l POV -- Pilgrim standing in the pasture with Tom crouching the grass waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom is still sitting in the grass, just where we left him waiting patiently. Pilgrim is still out in the pasture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afternoon shadows cross the ranch. Tom is in the exact sa spot and position. Pilgrim is somewhat closer -- but stil a distance -- watching him. Frank rides back from work. As he passes Tom, the two nod if nothing usually is going on. Frank rides up to the bar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace is flicking the television -- repeating the only th channels over and over... Annie works at her computer, surrounded by work. She noti the time, gets a thought and dials the phone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Booker... Oh, hello, Frank.  This is Annie MacLean... I was  wondering, has-... (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh... And Pilgrim?... (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still?... Uh-huh... (politely cheery)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay then. Thank you. She hangs up, pauses, then speaks to the window out loud for Grace to hear --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's still sitting in that damn  field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (w/o looking at her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they call it a pasture. Annie looks at her as if to say the last thing I need to a lesson on the local lingo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go see what's going on, then  get something to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky is changing colors, the temperature has dropped. is still sitting in the grass, although someone has broug him a blanket for his shoulders. Pilgrim is in the pastur but now -- he too is motionless, looking back at Tom. The sound of a car makes Tom turn to see Annie driving up She gets out, stands by the car with a proprietary air,  watching Tom and Pilgrim. Grace remains in the car. There sound. She turns to see Diane coming out of the house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's coffee inside... I was just  bringing this to Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind if I did? I'd like to  talk to him. Diane, knowing full well Tom ain't in a talking mood, han her a cup...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. (seeing Grace in car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does your daughter want to come  inside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, no, we're going to dinner... Is  this the way to the pasture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pasture? Oh, that stretch of field near  the hill? Yeah. She's gone. Annie grimaces, then crosses the hillside to  where Tom is squatting down. She appears to his side and, without speaking, tries to indicates she has his coffee b leaning it toward him. Tom sees her and accepts it with a grateful nod. Annie waits. Nothing happens. Feeling fooli she begins to walk back. At some point, she turns to see Pilgrim moving across the pasture toward Tom. He stops in front of him, just a few away. Tom says something to him. Annie is intrigued -- an knows enough to stay quiet now. She watches Pilgrim walk to him. She watches as Tom gets up and pats Pilgrim's sca head. In spite of herself, Annie is somewhat moved by thi Only we see Grace, peering out from the car, seeing this of communion as well. Only we see her reaction to it. As Tom turns and walks back to the ranch, Pilgrim follows As he passes Annie, all he says is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From now on, leave your phone  somewhere else... As he moves past her, Annie responds;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I have business calls I have  to -- Tom keeps heading for the barn as he suggests, without tu back;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then drop off Grace in the morning,  go on back and do your business.  Come pick her up around dinner. Standing there, Annie has the impulse to respond to this  suggestion, but has no idea what to say and saying it wou make much sense since Tom is already out of ear shot. Diane appears from the house and calls out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. MacLean -- why don't you and  daughter stay for dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh uh, thank you. No, we don't want to  impose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No imposition. Plenty of food. Gonna  get pretty dark soon. Hard to find a  place. Annie looks up to the alien sky and realizes she's right. looks to Grace, who doesn't seem to oppose the idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone sits around the kitchen table. Joe, still wearin his hat, eyes Annie and Grace with acute curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, take off the hat -- I'm not  going to say it again. Joe obeys. Diane puts the last of the serving plates on t table -- pork chops, potatoes, gravy, peas, bread... And bowl of mixed salad. The boy can't help eyeing how the  "vegetarians" will act. Annie and Grace eye the food. Annie reaches out for a ser ladle, picking up Grace's plate to serve her as Grace rea for a piece of bread, when:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Lord, we are humbly thankful  for... Annie and Grace freeze as Frank continues his prayer -- t notice everyone's head bowed slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continues)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: these gifts. For the blessings on our  home, our family and our guests. Bless  those that aren't as fortunate. Bless  all God's creatures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen. Everyone begins eating. Annie and Grace breath a sigh of Silence. Utensils hitting plates, the only sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bank out us a couple more men to run  the cattle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should be fine, then. Beat. Annie and Grace listen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teacher asked me why we raise Black  Angus-Herefords 'stead of Pure Herefords.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her they suit the weather better.  Their udders are black, 'stead of pink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't get burned by the sun bouncing  off the snow. And they're good mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our daddy raised Pure Herefords. Silence... Eating... Annie tries her hand at conversation

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, that's interesting. I always  wondered when I went into a restaurant  what was the difference between a regular  steak or a Black Angus steak. I couldn't  taste any difference although I could  swear one was more tender. I didn't know  there was that big a difference between  cows... (silence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been on a cow farm before. I  must say, the bulls seem to have the  best time of it. Just laying around the  fields all day until they're asked to... (uncomfortable)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: do their... work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, get born a bull, got a ninety  percent chance of getting castrated and  served up as hamburger. On a balance I  reckon I'd choose being a cow. (to Grace)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind passing that salad  young lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Peterson's holding up for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine. Comfortable. I still can't  get used to how dark it gets around here,  though. When we leave the ranch, I  always hold my breath until I can see  the motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (innocently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Tom, while you're working on  that horse of theirs, Annie and Grace  should move into the old Creek house. Diane and Tom react accordingly; Diane hiding her annoyan Tom hiding his surprise and pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's using it. Silly for her to be  driving back and forth when she don't  know her way around that well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I know Peterson's. Old place is as  good as falling down around your ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're already all settled in, Frank.  Anyway, I'm sure Annie wants her privacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's got doors, Diane. Private as can be.  Tom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a problem with that. It's up  to Annie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's worth it, really? I mean, how  much longer do you think you need to work  with Pilgrim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's up to Pilgrim. Everyone waits on Annie's answer as she considers this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace is on the phone with Robert. Annie is packing thing up. Grace is telling him about the day;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Me, too. Why don't you come  one weekend? Annie reacts to this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have more room because we're  moving onto the ranch. They have this  empty house near this creek. It's  actually pretty... OK... I love you. (to Annie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad wants to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert is burning the midnight oil in the study with file all around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey... She sounds like she's doing  all right. How is she? Grace exits into the bathroom. Annie talks softly;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cautious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. She seems to be getting more  comfortable on the ranch, which is why  I said yes to this move. But, whenever  it's just the two of us, I don't know...  Anyway... what's happening with the  Delco lawsuit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking forever. I just got an additional  list of sixty-two employees to interview  before Monday. I don't know how I'm going  to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's good that you're there. Robert didn't mean to validate his separation from them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, how are you doing in Marlboro  country? Is the magazine complaining at  all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but nothing I can't handle. Lucy  tells me she thinks Gottchalks's  plotting, but what else is new.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When are you coming home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I just asked that myself  tonight. He doesn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then... maybe I will take some  time... come visit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Beat. Annie knows Robert needed an invitation from her. B she can't do it. Robert tries again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I miss you, Annie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. We miss you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night. Awkwardly, they hang up. Grace exits the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ask him to come visit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You already did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he mention it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resumes packing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he's going to think about it.  You want me to pack for you? Grace looks at her disapprovingly as she passes to go to bathroom. Annie registers this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diane is washing windows while listening to an audio book her tape player. Through the windows, she sees: Joe and the Twins helping Annie and Grace move into the C House. Diane has conflicting feelings about this. She continues work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VARIOUS SHOTS of ANNIE CONNECTING HERSELF BACK TO THE RES THE WORLD, BY PLUGGING IN HER COMPUTER, FAX, ETC... Grace is in the other room, as she was in the motel. Alon With no television, she is just listening to her music la on the couch. The two women remain separate no matter whe they are. But we see a small difference. Grace rises and walks to t window. She looks out; POV: She sees people working about the ranch. Maybe Joe i among them -- riding his horse as he works. Or maybe it's just a vision of people with tasks to complete -- who do with pride, discipline and clarity. Grace looks out the window longingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cloud of dust. A dozen or so horses are running in an a by the stables. Tom is riding among them, holding a long with an orange flag at the end of it, waving it at the yo horses, making them run away from him. The colts stay clo together. One of the horses, PILGRIM, stays at a distance to himself. Grace watches from along the railing. She alternates her  attention from the horses... to Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we're doing here, Grace, is  trying to get him to learn how to  be a horse again. He cracks the flag, the horses move together...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others already know, see. That's  how they are in the wild -- herd  animals... (cracks the flag)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...When they've got a problem, like  they have now with me and this flag,  they look to each other. But old  Pilgrim there has forgotten. I'm the  rock and they're the hard place. He  thinks he hasn't got a friend in the  whole wild world... C.U. on GRACE, who clearly feels the same way... but want desperately not to. She watches him ride off towards Pilg who has stopped like all the others at the far end of the ring. He stands by himself, tossing his head, snorting, n wanting to be around other horses. Tom cracks the flag,  keeping them moving. Pilgrim does his own private dance. Tom rides by Grace and hands her the stick;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold this for a minute... Grace stiffens. She doesn't want to, but she's afraid to "No" to Tom. He just insists by tossing it to her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold onto it, go on... She's forced to catch it. He turns and rides away, chasin down Pilgrim, trying to edge him toward the herd. For a  moment, he has him breaking to the left with the horses. as soon as he's clear of Tom, he separates himself and co to stop on his own. Tom rides back to Grace, taking back the flag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get there, Grace. As he says this, he flashes a small, reassuring smile and little wink. Grace melts just a little. As he rides away. Annie appears, having come from the Creek House. She call

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace? The clinic just called...  They had to change your physical  therapy appointment. We have to  leave now. Grace frowns a little -- her mother's "perfect timing." A approaches the arena, watching Tom riding. As he passes h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Annie... Annie notices how he says her name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Booker... He flashes a smile in her direction and Annie's expressio comically matches her daughter's reaction. She quickly co it, however. Her eyes follow him as he glides around the  arena. It's like watching a great ballet -- his control o horses, his effortlessness, his grace, his strength... Sh smiles to herself in appreciation. Then catches herself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Grace)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got everything you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I had everything I need, I wouldn't  be going to physical therapy. Tom approaches as he overhears Grace respond;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to cheer her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, come on. Would you like to stay  in town for dinner? Maybe see what  movie's playing tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? There's no food in the house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I just thought... forget it. He's getting a clearer view of their relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, we're branding here  tomorrow. If you two want to come  by to watch or give a hand, you're  welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Branding? (sarcastic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't branded in years. Tom chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, I don't, honey. Branding? Oooh...  I think we'd just be in Mr. Booker's  way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as you don't get in the way of  the branding iron, it doesn't matter too  much. Annie smiles. She turns to Grace, questioningly. Grace sa matter-of-factly, to prove her point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I watched Margo Neuberger get a  tattoo. Tom squints. Annie shrugs and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. As Grace and Annie walk to the car, Tom says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Grace -- maybe we can get your  mom to put me and you branding on the  cover of her magazine. Start a whole  new fashion craze. They continue walking as Grace smiles, enjoying being sin out for his joke. Annie responds, almost flirtatiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try not to fall off your high horse,  Mr. Booker. Tom tips his hat and rides away... Annie smiles and nods. Grace doesn't like their sudden familiarity. Or her mothe coy manner. As they enter the Suburban, Grace asks point

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you call Dad today? Annie is caught off guard. Tom, riding in the arena, catches himself looking after t then goes riding after Pilgrim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The air smells of scorched flesh. There is nothing but NO Calves, separated from their mothers, "cry." They are mov out through a series of connected pens into a narrow chut and then one by one into a holding pen. They're clamped a lowered sideways onto a table and given a shot, a yellow  insect tag in one ear, branded, then sent back to their  mother's. The bulls, in a pen by themselves, stand haught paying no attention. Frank helps "doctor" the calves. Joe brands. Annie and Grace are standing by the railing, watching wit mixture of fascination and disgust. Tom moves in the feeder pen, waist deep in calves, moving through the chute. He looks to Annie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, over there, you want to make  yourself useful? It isn't a question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank, I got you a volunteer! Annie and Grace realize they have no choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good... firm but gentle... (Grace opens her eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hurts but he'll get over it. Grace smiles proudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You handled that pretty well. Think  it's time you earn your keep around  here. So, when we're not working  and when you don't have your therapy,  I'd like you to help out with the  horses... Rubbing them, cleaning up  the stalls... You think you can  handle that? Grace knows him well enough to know;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not a question, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're catching on. Grace smiles. -- Annie turns and, not looking where she's doing, trips a calf, falling down. And calves, coming down the chute,  start to run towards her. Suddenly, Tom grabs her by the and pulls her to safety. He helps her up and dusts her of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not wanting to smile,  but...)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is cocktail hour yet? Tom laughs. She takes a big breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ranch is colored in amber light. Near the house, two long tables pushed together to make o long one... A gentle breeze ruffles the tablecloth. Every is seated for a meal. We hear laughter and conversation.. parachute into the middle of the moments; -- Hank helping with his wife get to their three children sit still for dinner... -- Diane organizing the women and their various plates of dishes... -- The Ranch Hand piling up their plates and kidding each other... -- Joe is instructing Grace on the various sauces for the ribs. The Twins are making fun of him behind his back. -- Tom and Smokey are barbecuing, the last one to sit. -- Frank assists his frail mother, ELLEN BOOKER, at the t filling her plate with all the things she can't reach for

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The faces are beautiful. Laughing. Eating. Everyone is ta and exhausted after a long day, but filled with life and  eager to live it. The tables are covered with heavy food. The communion at this table is as much a part of the ritu as the branding itself... Annie and Grace look different to us. Tanned from the sun their bodies sore -- they feel softened, yet more vital. the artifice had been worn off... the armor of urban life the table thrives with conversations, we focus on: Annie and Ellen Booker. Annie looks calmer than we've see her -- and more naturally beautiful. She is seated beside Ellen Booker. We sense they have been talking for a while Annie is so sincerely interested in listening to her, she hardly touched her own plate...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... he was a blacksmith by trade, my  father. My grandson Joe was named  for him. But he always dreamed of  having his own place and raising  horses... We see Tom a few places down and across from Annie and hi mother -- but fully aware of their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd heard of some land. What's  Stockett now. Rode out there. Got off  his horse and walked about as far as  he could in one way. Then he walked as  far as he could another way and  another until he got back to where he  started and that's where he put his  roots down... That's where my husband  and I ranched and raised Frank and  Tommy... She motions proudly to Tom who looks up. Annie smiles to He looks to her with gratitude for the respect she's show his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite a different life from what you  know, I expect. Which place to you  call home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I was born in London, but my  father was an ambassador and we  moved constantly. I've lived in a lot  of places but I don't really know what  I'd call home. Tom listens to this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ambassador! My! That's very  important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a wonderful man. She looks to Tom and he can sense a sadness around this i eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Grace)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sure hope you're gonna eat more  than that, young lady. You're a  growing girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never eaten this much in my  life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably never worked so hard,  neither. Those arms of yours are  gonna be pretty sore tomorrow. I'll  give you a little bit of ointment I  make. It's a magic recipe my Mama  gave me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We used to call Diane's mother  Medicine Woman. None of us never went  to the doctor when she was alive. Annie and Grace listen in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad she wasn't here for old  Henry Vanoker...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much would have helped him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never got that whole story, what  happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Henry was changing a flat tire on  his truck over on 118 when that... (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... two-hundred-year-old jack he has  gives way and the side of that truck  come slamming down on that rock he  calls head... There's laughter -- everyone knows Old Henry. Except:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knocked him out for a while. He woke  up, finished putting on the tire and  drove himself to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Fool... Darling, pass down those peas  for me, thank you. Annie and Grace don't know how to respond... But everyone takes it their stride as they continue eating... Grace notices Joe is whispering something to Frank, who n his head and speaks to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh, Joe here has something to say. Joe stands, somewhat formally, with his hat on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wrote this for you Grandma... Mrs. Booker, and Diane, beam. Annie and Grace don't know to expect. Joe stands straight as an arrow and recites a from memory... At first, Annie and Grace appear to be embarrassed for th but soon they can't help but be won over by his guilessne He finishes and everyone applauds. Hank's wife asks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was lovely. Who wrote that,  Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wrote it myself, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now son, you tell 'em when it came  from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be honest, I can't say I did it all  myself. My grandma helped me get the  words right. OOoo's and aah's and smiles and conversations erupting ov each other. Only we see, Grace looking over to Joe who gives her kick shy grin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising his beer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd like to welcome Annie and  Grace to their first branding...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And next time, Miss Annie, you can run  down the calves...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll drink to that... Everyone toasts and drinks. Annie and Tom exchange a look She smiles, but not in a alluring way -- rather, in a gra way. Grateful for this brief moment of community and good feeling. And somehow, Tom knows what she's feeling. No one notices this silent exchange -- except for Diane, sees everything that's going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Women are bringing in dishes and plates and food from tables through the house and into the kitchen. Annie is a them, feeling apart of the group. She enters carrying a l bowl, that held the corn. Diane is replacing newly-cleaned forks and knives in her  dining room drawers, above which are several FAMILY PICTU

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (referring to clean bowl)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where does this go, Diane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you can just set up on the dining  table. I have to rearrange my shelves  tomorrow. Annie complies. She notices the framed pictures on the wa the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this Mr. Booker? Tom's  grandfather? Diane looks at a faded photo circa late 1800's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-mm. I never knew him. He died  before Frank and I met. This here's... (another photo)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Tom's mother and father...  there's little Frank and Tom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She calls him Tommy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always did. I think she favored him a  little. You tend to when you have more  than one, even though you love 'em all  the same. She studies the old faces of Tom's Parents -- although 20 Century people, there is still a pioneering strength in t visage... a stoicism and power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting away forks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha, she loves telling this story about  how when he was two years old, he ran off.  They found him in the barn, sleeping  between two giant hooves of a Percheron  stallion. She said that horse was  protecting him and nobody could convince  her otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a little confused though. The ranch  Ellen was talking about -- that's not this  one? Diane is sorting silverware throughout the following:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. See, Frank and Tom were raised near  the Clark's Fork River, right between the  Pryor and Beartooth Mountains. Beautiful  piece of land. But they had this uncle  Ned -- useless man, never interested in  ranching. And when the grandparents died,  he left for the city and sent word  through lawyers he wanted his claim to  the land so he could sell it. Three years  of legation broke their father. Frank took  it all in stride, but Tom... Tom loved that  land. I don't think he ever got over it --  His home being sold out from under him.  Seeing his father like that. Once he and  Frank got their folks set up in a new  place, Tom left... went off. We didn't see  him for years... Annie is intrigued by what she's learning about Tom.  Something outside the window catches her eyes. She watche POV;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom and Frank, on either side to Ellen, are escorting her a car that will drive her home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie wanders out, passing Grace and Joe on her way out. are sitting in a glider. As Annie exits O.C., we hear the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you always wear that hat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it fits my head. You want to  try it on? Grace doesn't know if she should. Annie continues towards Tom who's sitting in a rocker pla with the twins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show us again! Come on! One more time!  It's my turn now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, al right. Hold out your  finger. Annie takes a seat nearby and watches as Tom holds out th first finger of his right hand. The Twins holds out his. splits his focus between Annie and the Twins as he takes small piece of rope out of his back pocket. He ties the e together making a loop. He puts the loop over the Twin's  finger. And holding the other end of the loop taut with h left hand, he draws one side of the cord over the other w the middle finger of his right hand. Then he rolls his ha over so it's under the loop, and back over it again, so t his finger is tip to tip with the Twin's. The loop seemin knotted around their touching fingertips, and can only be removed if their touch is broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The loop's knotted, right. (Twins nod)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like the only way to take it  off, is if we break our touch... (they nod)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch now... Annie and the Twins look down at the touching fingers as gently pulls the rope away, revealing they are still knot and without even breaking their touch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again! Again. One more time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. No, no. I only fall for that  once. Go inside now before your mother  starts hunting you down. Go on. The Twins exit. Annie and Tom make eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles, relaxes back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how was your first and last day of  branding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be so sure it's my last. There  are a few people back home I'd like  to put under a red hot iron. Tom looks at her with a sly expression, and notices she's shivering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got too much sun today...  Here... He takes his jacket and puts it around her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. He sits back down. Annie crosses her arms over her chest, looks around, unconsciously swinging her foot. Tom watche her leg. Annie notices him watching;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever just stand still for a  minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stand still too long in New York  you get hit by a bicycle messenger. (smiles wryly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, sometimes, I get the feeling,  Mr. Booker, that you're laughing at me.  Why is that? Tom shrugs. Annie waits a beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your cue to say you're not  laughing at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see, you write both sides of the  conversation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a man's world, Mr. Booker. Most  women have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe I am laughing a bit... I  just thought, as long as you're here,  it would be nice for you to relax into  the place a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (understanding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... It's beautiful country, I'll give  you that. And I could see having some  kind of vacation place. Retreat. But I  don't know how you do it full time. Don't  you miss the rest of the world?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that to miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha... if you've never lived in a city  with museums, theater, music, restaurants,  uh... god, a million things, then it's  something I can't explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks, teasing a bit)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does Chicago count?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lived in Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was first married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were married to a woman in  Chicago? Tom likes disturbing her picture of him as the predictabl cowboy. He smiles;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I once heard Itzhak Perlman guest star  with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra.  He played Rachmaninov's Vocalize Opus 34.  No. 14. It was one of the most beautiful  pieces of music I ever heard. I actually  forgot where I was for a time. (Annie is floored)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem surprised?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not wanting to insult)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I, uh... you didn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just who's been laughing at who here? Tom says this with a wry smile. Annie returns with a smil as an understanding is reached between them: they've both stereotyped the other. They are both pleased -- and attra by what they don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace is fast asleep, exhausted. She does not stir when t phone rings. Annie picks up from her own bed, awakened, still dressed her branding clothes, having just passed out on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT: Robert, alone, in the vast apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you guys were going to call  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Robert, I'm sorry. We were so tired  from the branding. Grace barely made it  to her bed and I didn't have the energy  to take my clothes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh well... branding will do that to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh-huh. You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Actually, today was a good day.  You should have seen her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I did. The sound of self-pity was so obvious for both of them, s Robert quickly re-groups, resorting to something he knows important to her;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, uh the real reason I called,  actually, was to tell you I saw Lucy  at Jo-Jo's tonight and she seems very  worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently, Gottschalk's been seen around  town lunching with some very prominent  magazine editors. Lucy said she tried to  call you, but no one answered so she faxed  you the list of names. She said one of  them have contracts up fairly soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I didn't look at my faxes today. We  left before sunrise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, I hope you're not endangering  your position. Listen, if you need to  come back and you want me to come take  over, for a while, I'll work it out. I  mean, the firm's got other lawyers, but  the magazine's got only one of you. After a day of hard work and simple pleasures, Annie begi succumb to old anxieties and pressures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie is awake reading the faxes Lucy sent. One after oth As she flips through them, one falls to the floor near th She gets down on all fours to retrieve and sees something under the bed. AN OLD, BATTERED CELLO CASE. She pulls it to find the initials R.B. carved on the top. She opens it find papers, receipts, bills -- all from Tom's married li

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom rides a young colt along the creek. He hears footstep He turns and sees Annie running along the creek on the ot side. He stops to watch. When his horse SNORTS, Annie loo up to see him. She stops. He tips his hat to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've decided it's impossible to  properly say hello in this place  without a hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A jogger, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't jog, Mr. Booker. I run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky for you. The grizzlies around  here only go for joggers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I can survive rush hour, I figure I  can handle grizzlies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sleeping all right in that house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't sleep all right anywhere. But  the house is fine. Tom walks his horse across the creek to her, comfortable the silence. Annie moves about, uncomfortable in the wait

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's R.B.? Tom is finding Annie's blunt curiosity more endearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found this old cello case filled with  bills and receipts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about that. I thought everything  got cleared out. R.B. is my wife...  ex-wife... Rachel. We used to live in  that house  together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you lived in Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were an editor, not a  reporter? Annie smiles and nods, realizing she's asking too many qu She tries to casually reach out to touch the horse's head it's too abrupt and the horse tosses his head away, takin couple of steps back. Annie is embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a way with animals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. He's young. Just hold  out your hand a little lower so he can  get the smell of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes. I forgot. She does and the horse sniffs at her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you ride anymore? Grace told  me you used to ride when she was  younger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She did? Annie is somewhat moved by her daughter telling him that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, really. No time mostly. A cold wind blows. She folds her arms across her breasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it was supposed to be spring. Tom can't help but notice her nipples are hard from the c He looks away. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you shy, Mr. Booker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just polite. Well, maybe you'd like  to try riding again, some time before  you go home. Annie is struck by the words "before you go home." Tom am off on his horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enjoy the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too. Annie steps across the rocks at the ford, crossing the cr Her foot slips, one of her shoes goes into the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need a lift?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can handle it! She crosses the creek. She turns, giving him a small wave touches his hat. She runs off. Tom watches her go, head d concentrating...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tense Annie is having a difficult phone with DAVID GOTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... David, we've been behind a day or  two before. But Lucy just Fedexed me all  the material and it'll be approved by  the end of the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If nothing goes wrong. If the faxes don't  go down. If the phone lines are opened.  I can't have this magazine hitting the  streets by the skin of its ass, Annie. During David's lines, Diane has entered, carrying fresh t -- she crosses into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on! This is such bullshit! The  work is getting done, David. Lucky keeps  me on top of everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy isn't you. We're losing something  without you being here. Now, I know this  is a rough time for you, but I think we  should make another arrangement. Without Annie's awareness, Diane re-enters and takes her leaving, so she can take in all of Annie's things; her  business "office," books, etc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell does that mean? How much  more do I have to do to prove how  important this magazine is to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this magazine is so important to you  Annie, why are you in Montana? Diane can't help but notice a slight vulnerability in Ann

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, this is what we're going to do.  Finish up this issue. I'll set up a  conference call in a few weeks. Just  you, me and your lawyer and we'll  just work this out so that everyone  will be taken care of. Fair enough? Annie is now aware of Diane's presence and chooses to pla cool. It's not the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, yes... Sure, David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Speak to you then. He hangs up. Annie forces a smile to Diane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. You're all doing too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's... I wanted to tell you that,  if you'd like, you being so busy, I  could take Grace to her therapy  exercises for you. I have to go in  once a week for shopping anyway. Annie doesn't know whether or not to accept.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... Well... thank you very much. I  don't -- Before she finishes her line, the Phone Rings again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. (to phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Hi, yeah, I just spoke to him.  Oh, you know David, Mr. Strong Arm... Diane feels out of place and exits. Annie doesn't notice  until she hears the door close. She pushes back her hair takes a deep breath. She looks out through the side windo and sees: Grace and Joe doing chores. Grace looks involved and not all self-conscious. A moment of gratitude and calm for An

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilgrim bursts out of a chute and into the riding arena. runs to the far end and abruptly stops. Tom is holding th orange flagstick, and coiled rope, coming through a gate  into the arena, crossing to the middle of the ring. Somet in his demeanor tells us that fun and game are over. Pilgrim and Tom stand there, motionless, eyeing each othe Pilgrim snorts and takes a few, small steps backward. Tom takes a beat, then starts slowly towards Pilgrim, lifting flag and "cracking" it. At the sound, Pilgrim whirls away him and runs, around the arena. He starts to slow, lookin Tom. Again, Tom cracks the flag and Pilgrim runs, round a round the arena... like a ringmaster, Tom keeps Pilgrim  moving, cracking the flag. Something about Tom's demeanor tells us it isn't going we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, carrying a saddle, comes around the side of the barn Through the slats, he sees Grace working in the barn,  watering a horse. She has stopped and is looking through cracks of Pilgrim's stall at him. She turns and sees Tom  through the slats. She goes back to work as Tom comes to barn door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come and take a ride with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk towards his pick-up truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you drive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drive? I'm not old enough yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's never too soon to start. He enters the passenger side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have all day. She hesitates and gets into the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace doesn't know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put the key in and turn it. (Grace obeys)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
